channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-16993] BucketCache throw java.io.IOException: Invalid HFile block magic when DATA_BLOCK_ENCODING set to DIFF
item.description:
hbase-site.xml setting
<property>
<name>hbase.bucketcache.bucket.sizes</name>
<value>16384,32768,40960, 46000,49152,51200,65536,131072,524288</value>
</property>
<property>
<name>hbase.bucketcache.size</name>
<value>16384</value>
</property>
<property>
<name>hbase.bucketcache.ioengine</name>
<value>offheap</value>
</property>
<property>
<name>hfile.block.cache.size</name>
<value>0.3</value>
</property>
<property>
<name>hfile.block.bloom.cacheonwrite</name>
<value>true</value>
</property>
<property>
<name>hbase.rs.cacheblocksonwrite</name>
<value>true</value>
</property>
<property>
<name>hfile.block.index.cacheonwrite</name>
<value>true</value>
</property

n_splits = 200
create 'usertable',{NAME =>'family', COMPRESSION => 'snappy', VERSIONS => 1,DATA_BLOCK_ENCODING => 'DIFF',CONFIGURATION => {'hbase.hregion.memstore.block.multiplier' => 5}},

{DURABILITY => 'SKIP_WAL'}

,{SPLITS => (1..n_splits).map {|i| "user#

{1000+i*(9999-1000)/n_splits}

"}}

load data
bin/ycsb load hbase10 -P workloads/workloada -p table=usertable -p columnfamily=family -p fieldcount=10 -p fieldlength=100 -p recordcount=200000000 -p insertorder=hashed -p insertstart=0 -p clientbuffering=true -p durability=SKIP_WAL -threads 20 -s

run

bin/ycsb run hbase10 -P workloads/workloadb -p table=usertable -p columnfamily=family -p fieldcount=10 -p fieldlength=100 -p operationcount=20000000 -p readallfields=true -p clientbuffering=true -p requestdistribution=zipfian -threads 10 -s

log info
2016-11-02 20:20:20,261 ERROR [RW.default.readRpcServer.handler=36,queue=21,port=6020] bucket.BucketCache: Failed reading block fdcc7ed6f3b2498b9ef316cc8206c233_44819759 from bucket cache
java.io.IOException: Invalid HFile block magic: \x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00

at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.BlockType.read(BlockType.java:167)

item.summary: BucketCache throw java.io.IOException: Invalid HFile block magic when DATA_BLOCK_ENCODING set to DIFF

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.

comments.comment: When u test same setup with table having no DataBlockEncoding, does things work normally as expected? Will u be able to check and confirm?

when i alter table's DATA_BLOCK_ENCODING like this
disable 'testtable'
hbase(main):002:0> alter 'testtable',NAME=>'family',DATA_BLOCK_ENCODING =>'NONE'
hbase(main):003:0> enable 'testtable'

the server it's work on

when alter table's DATA_BLOCK_ENCODING back to DIFF and restart server
the server thow exception like this
2016-11-02 21:36:18,616 ERROR [RW.default.readRpcServer.handler=41,queue=26,port=6020] bucket.BucketCache: Failed reading block 01113ef67d504fc78888202a164d4ddf_55884150 from bucket cache
java.io.IOException: Invalid HFile block magic: \x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00

when i remove hbase-site.xml (disable cache for L2)
<!--property>
<name>hbase.bucketcache.bucket.sizes</name>
<value>16384,32768,40960, 46000,49152,51200,65536,131072,524288</value>
</property>
<property>
<name>hbase.bucketcache.size</name>
<value>16384</value>
</property>
<property>
<name>hbase.bucketcache.ioengine</name>
<value>offheap</value>
</property-->

the server work ok,my hbase version is 1.1.3

thank you very much

when i alter table's DATA_BLOCK_ENCODING like this

So after alter table, u mean u again inserted data and try read back? Or u just alter table to NONE encoding and still use old data to scan?

i found that exception on online server ,so i chcek in test env
step 1(create table DATA_BLOCK_ENCODING with diff )
disable 'testtable'
drop 'testtable'
create 'testtable',{NAME =>'family', COMPRESSION => 'snappy', VERSIONS => 1,DATA_BLOCK_ENCODING => 'DIFF',CONFIGURATION => {'hbase.hregion.memstore.block.multiplier' => 5}},

{DURABILITY => 'SKIP_WAL'}

,{SPLITS => (1..n_splits).map {|i| "user#

{1000+i*(9999-1000)/n_splits}

"}}
setp 2 load data
bin/ycsb load hbase10 -P workloads/workloada -p table=testtable -p columnfamily=family -p fieldcount=10 -p fieldlength=100 -p recordcount=100000000 -p insertorder=hashed -p insertstart=0 -p clientbuffering=true -p durability=SKIP_WAL -threads 20 -s

then i found exception on server the log is:

2016-11-03 15:25:18,824 ERROR [hfile-prefetch-1478157917790] bucket.BucketCache: Failed reading block 765a8640906346c990e5f581f302761a_2022849 from bucket cache
java.io.IOException: Invalid HFile block magic: \x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.BlockType.parse(BlockType.java:154)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.BlockType.read(BlockType.java:167)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.HFileBlock.<init>(HFileBlock.java:253)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.HFileBlock$1.deserialize(HFileBlock.java:134)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.HFileBlock$1.deserialize(HFileBlock.java:121)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.bucket.BucketCache.getBlock(BucketCache.java:427)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.CombinedBlockCache.getBlock(CombinedBlockCache.java:85)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.HFileReaderV2.getCachedBlock(HFileReaderV2.java:266)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.HFileReaderV2.readBlock(HFileReaderV2.java:403)
at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.HFileReaderV2$1.run(HFileReaderV2.java:203)
at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:471)
at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:262)
at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.access$201(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:178)
at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.run(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:292)
at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1145)
at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)

I test all data_block_encoding ,the phenomenon is kile this

DATA_BLOCK_ENCODING load run restart

DIFF | Must happen | Must happen |Must happen |
FAST_DIFF | Must happen | Must happen |Must happen |
PREFIX | sometime | sometime |not happen in test|
PREFIX_TREE | Must happen | Must happen |Must happen |
NONE | sometime | sometime | sometime |

test way is

1. drop table and create table
2. load data
3. run
4. restart server

load 100% write
run 90% read 10% wrtie

confirm this exception caused by by property hbase.bucketcache.bucket.sizes，when i set this property to default then server work ok,my setting is:

16384,32768,40960, 46000,49152,51200,65536,131072,524288
caused by hbase.bucketcache.bucket.sizes incorrect value
Why is this not a bug @liubangchen ? If folks use non-standard bucket.sizes, do they run into your issue above? Thank you.

If I set hbase.bucketcache.bucket.sizes to "16384,32768,40960, 46000,49152,51200,65536,131072,524288", the server throws exception "Invalid HFile block magic", I think this bug may be caused by " bucketAllocator.allocateBlock(len) " , which return wrong offset. Yesterday I'm not sure if it is a bug or not, so I confirm it again.

thank you very much

Must be a multiple of 1024 else you will run into
'java.io.IOException: Invalid HFile block magic' when you go to read from cache.
If you specify no values here, then you pick up the default bucketsizes set
in code (See BucketAllocator#DEFAULT_BUCKET_SIZES).

It has to be multiple of 1024? I took a look in refguide and don't see anything to that effect. I think it a bug liubangchen. Let me reopen if only to check config is 1024 multiple and to update refguide. Dump any of your findings in here please.

Class BucketEntry calculate offset like as :

long offset()

{ // Java has no unsigned numbers long o = ((long) offsetBase) & 0xFFFFFFFF; o += (((long) (offset1)) & 0xFF) << 32; return o << 8; }

private void setOffset(long value)

{ assert (value & 0xFF) == 0; value >>= 8; offsetBase = (int) value; offset1 = (byte) (value >> 32); }

If offset not multiple of 1024 , the method offset() will return wrong value. if bucketsizes must be multiple of 1024, probably waste memory .

Why you don't directly use offset value in setOffset of calss BucketEntry ?

-1 overall

I added you as a contribtutor @liubangchen so you should be able to attach a patch now (Remove rather than comment out code... thanks)

directly use offset value in setOffset of calss BucketEntry,otherwise bucket.sizes must be a multiple of 1024 else you will run into
'java.io.IOException: Invalid HFile block magic' when you go to read from cache
Hi @Stack, I am a newcomer in submitting patch. Would you like to teach me how to submit or review patch.thanks

This message was automatically generated.

Instead of long having int+ byte as offset is being done for heap size reduction I believe. But we already have 2 other longs here and the save (3 bytes) seems not that big compared to cur heap size per BucketEntry. Am ok to the change as shown in the patch. Stack wdyt?

My personal point of view, directly use offset value is better, for the following reasons:

1. Now the machine memory is very large (we are using the machine memory 512GB, do not consider the use of high-speed SSD as a cache media), cache may be set to very large (30GB +), if not use long there is the risk of overflow
2. Assuming that each Bucket is an integer multiple of 1024, but when a data block is compressed directly cache it, data block is likely not the standard size of the data block, this will waste storage space

My English is not so good, I hope you can understand what I mean.Thanks

long we use. So overflow is really possible? What will be the max cache size we can go if we consider all block size as say 2 KB. or 1 KB. (Am not expecting any HFile block below that)

Ya I also agree to change this to direct long offset
You are right, the offset is stored in five bytes can not overflow.I don't understand correctly.Thanks

Change seems good to me (I can't see why original author did the byte shift gymnastics other than as you ruminate Anoop Sam John, to save a few bytes). Patch looks good to me. liubangchen, what is your change in the test about? You make arbitrary sizings to prove your change works: i.e. 44600?

I want to confirm that the bucket.sizes runs correctly with not multiple of 1024. So I insert some changes in this unit test. I am not sure if it is necessary. I will remove it if not. Original author do the did the byte shift gymnastics. Maybe he did not thinking about such large cache, and using int can save some a few bytes. That is just my assumption. I wish the original author Anoop Sam John would like to help me to review the patch is correct or necessary.Thnaks

Am not the original author of this. So sorry I also dont the real reason behind this. I believe as we make offset as long, we wont get any overflow. 3 bytes per entry saving is less compared to original heap size per BucketEntry what we have now. So am ok with this change.
Thank you sir.
chunhui shen Could you take a look here? Thanks.
+1 to change to long. If the IOEngine is persisted even then this change will work right - Just asking?

+1 for the patch, also doing like this in our internal branch.

PS:
In the origin code of BucketCache, use 48 bits to support 256TB cache space (save 3 bytes (not using long) per BucketEntry )
The 48 bits includes BucketEntry#offsetBase(4 bytes) + BucketEntry#offset1(1byte) + Reserved 8 zero bits(1byte),
the reserved 8 zero bits means the bucket size must be a multiple of 256,
from the issue description, one of bucket size is configed to 46000, trigger the exception.

Anyway, it seems a unreadable and non-meaningful design.
Thanks liubangchen

Thanks chunhui shen for the check and clarification!

One minor comment for the v1 patch:


+        { 44600, null }, // TODO: why is 8k the default blocksize for these tests?

I guess we no longer need the TODO here and instead add some comment like "test non-multiple of 256 bucket size, see #HBASE-16993"?

Not a big deal to block the fix though, could be updated while committing

I'm leaving this one for you to commit gentlemen since I'm not quite involved here (Smile). stack Anoop Sam John ramkrishna.s.vasudevan chunhui shen

And good catch liubangchen
Thank you all.

Good Q.. Ya when we deal with FileIOEngine, which is persisted cache, this might break. The meta info is written to file with states as int and byte and when read back, suppose the new version with patch is there in RS, the read back to long will fail. So this is an incompatible change for file IOEngine.

I'm so sorry that ignore with this case,to compatible this change is to change the method offset() of BucketEntry like this :


long offset() { // Java has no unsigned numbers

      if(offsetBase>0){

        long o = ((long) offsetBase) & 0xFFFFFFFF;

        o += (((long) (offset1)) & 0xFF) << 32;

        return o << 8;

      }else{

        assert this.offset > 0;

        return this.offset;

      }

}

what is you views ？
Thanks.

It's a but ot not ?


 BucketAllocator allocator = new BucketAllocator(cacheCapacity, bucketSizes,

          backingMap, realCacheSize);

 backingMap = (ConcurrentHashMap<BlockCacheKey, BucketEntry>) ois

          .readObject();
It's correct in trunk,just find this at version 1.1.3

In trunk the above code was corrected by some recent JIRA. Your patch fixes the issue. Only thing is it will lead to incompatible change for those who try to use the bucket cache with persistent feature.
I think still we need to fix it and mark it as incompatible change.

Fixed by:


commit d91a28a450fc0f697bf78aab07543cd48f7dedfc

Author: tedyu <yuzhihong@gmail.com>

Date:   Mon Sep 5 17:29:44 2016 -0700



    HBASE-16460 Can't rebuild the BucketAllocator's data structures when BucketCache uses FileIOEngine (Guanghao Zhang)

For this to work, we would have to retain offsetBase and offset1 in the BucketEntry type? And I think there a legitimate case where BucketEntry starts at offsetBase == 0?

Lets just mark it an incompatible change (as per ramkrishna.s.vasudevan – man, we serialize using java serialization... no wonder it is slow!). Means this is a hbase 2.0 only change.

Change gets us support for > 256TB of memory (smile) but more importantly, being able to do sizes that are not multiples of 256. Thanks for the patch liubangchen. Let me take care of the wording issues pointed out by Yu Li on commit. See what you think of the release note I'll add now liubangchen. Edit it if not good by you.

Oh ya.. So the persisted cache was never working as such and the recent fix only fixed it. We can just mark it as incompatible and commit. Do we need change the serialization also? Not this issue may be in another. Any way we break it now for 2.0

So, this is an incompatible change. Looking, we just serialize out the cache w/o versioning using java serialization (TODO: Fix). So, I don't see a way of being able to read old persisted files. My thought is to add a protobuf version+metainfo at the head of the file we persist. If not present when I read a persisted file, I will remove the persisted file with WARNINGs and proceed w/ startup; means cache will come up cold. That good by you all?
You have a point Anoop Sam John. I think it means the fix is not confined to 2.0.0. It can be backported since persistence only works since above commit. Only 1.2.4 and 1.1.7 releases have the fix.

Ya. This is true. So I think overall persistence has never worked. So any branch after 1.2.4 and 1.1.8 will fix it. So now if we introduce protobuf for it - again we make upgrading from 1.2.4 to 2.0 incompatible. Is that fine?
+1 for this.

-1 overall

This is ready for commit Stack? We may have to update the jira title and description.. Now we dont need the bucket sizes to be multiple of 256 after this patch.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
Make it so bucket sizes no longer have to be exact multiple of 256 (side effect is we now can support caches > 256TB -- smile).

Incompatible change as the bucket entry format has changed. Means we cannot read persisted cache written in the old format. On restart, if present, the old persisted cache will be removed and we continue w/ startup; i.e. cache will not be unpopulated after startup (This behavior is 'standard' when we are unable to find or read the the persisted file -- so no change here).

Persisted file works in release 1.2.4 and 1.1.7. Previous to HBASE-16460, persisted file operation didn't work
